The Honor System is one of

legal system as well as Hopikns'

One of the principal purposes
of the Honor Commission is to
secure the cooperation of students and faculty in adherence
to the Honor System. Many times
in the past, the Honor Commission has been accused of neglecting this vital purpose. But the
Honor Commission is deeply concerned about student attitudes
toward the Honor System. To
this end, the Honor Commission
is opening up to public review
the most pressing problems confronting the Honor System today.
The purpose is to generate awareness on the part of the members
of the Hopkins Community of the
important issues facing us so
that we may be called upon to
make the vital decisions concerning the possible new directions of the Honor System.

JAY'S NEST
By JIM SLOAN
Assistant Sports Editor
UCLA has basketball, for Notre
Dame there is football, but at
Hopkins, it has to be lacrosse.
A winless football season and
a declining basketball record will
be overlooked in that first outing
against Mount Washington
March 18. Last year's Injuryplagued and not-too-successful
season may also be forgotten, for
in the words of many, "This is
the year."
The return of last year's injured stickmen, few losses due to
graduation, a powerful group of
enthusiastic sophomores, and
pre-season workouts figure to
make the Jay squad one of the
best in recent years. Injuries,
which were the main cause of the
disappointing season last year,
weigh in as perhaps the biggest
question mark to the success of
the 1967 campaign.
Early preparations
Last fall Coach Bob Scott instituted pre-season lacrosse practice sessions for the first time
since 1948. The main topics of
the meetings, which ran for six
weeks, were the offense, morale,
and physical conditioning. Winter workouts in the Athletic Center were begun at the conclusion
of the fall program. Consisting
of several calesthenics and
weight lifting exercises,the workouts emphasized mainly conditioning.
An organizational meeting was
held immediately after semester
break for coordination of the
regular spring training program.
Last Tuesday the Jays held the
first practice consisting of a light
workout, and the following day

with a strong match which ended with Rich pinning his man
near the end of the third period.
Steve Koyama, who has been experiencing a great deal of trouble
in the last few matches, lost a
very close contest, 6-5.

Top Talent Listed
Coach Scott termed his stickmen as talented and capable, but
he eyes a great deal of hard
work necessary to solve coordination problems. Competition
could be the keynote of the season, as there are several contenders for each position on the
contingent. Only five players
were lost last year via graduation, but among them were the
standouts Lucky Mallonee, Steve
Levy, and Mike Oidick. Last year's
frosh contingent, considered to
be one of the finest in many seasons, looks to add considerable
ability and enthusiasm to the
varsity.
Co-captains for the '67 campaign are hustling All-American
Jerry Schnydman and Bill Deitrich, another strong midfielder.
Having shared the scoring crown
with Schnydman last year, Phil
Kneip looks to be a big asset to
the Jays. Other valuable contenders for the midfielder position are Wayne Towns, Wes
Bachur, and Phil Parthemore.
